captions.text:
Matter is everywhere: we eat it, breathe it,
drink it; it is who we are. But what is matter?

The most basic particle physics definition
of matter comes down to one surprising rule:

the Pauli exclusion principle - or, essentially,
electrons hate being alike.

To understand why, we have to remember the
fact that every electron is exactly the same.

Not "kind of the same"… They're perfectly
identical. Just as you can at anytime, anywhere,

spontaneously write down the number three
and it will mean exactly, perfectly, three…

as if there were some everywhere-permeating
"three-ness" always available to produce a

three at your whim. It's the same case with
the electron: there's an everywhere-permeating

"electron-ness" called a "quantum field,"
and from that field every electron in existence

has been summoned, and they are all, exactly,
"electron".

So when someone says "every time you breathe,
you inhale a few of the same electrons that

used to be in Jesus or Mozart"… that's about
as deep as saying that every time you do arithmetic
you use the same number three as Archimedes.

What's more, just like you can call on the
"three-ness" to summon "negative-three", which

has all the exact same properties of three
except opposite and when it meets three they

annihilate - you can summon "anti-electron"
from the electron field and it will annihilate
electron when they meet.

Given that electrons are all exactly alike,
it might seem surprising that they actually

hate being like each other. Electrons despise
alikeness so much, in fact, that the universe

is forbidden from summoning two or more into
the same quantum state. This is called "the

Pauli Exclusion principle," and what it means
in practice is that you can't cram too much

matter into the same place – like a city
where building higher than one story is prohibited:
instead of skyscrapers, compounds sprawl outwards.

So at the most fundamental level, matter is
just any field (like "electron", "quark",

or "neutrino") from which you can summon particles
and anti-particles, but only one at every

point, which means that, quite literally,
matter is everything that takes up space.
Like Walmart.

title: Theory of Everything: What is Matter?

comments.author: Alperen Akküncü

comments.text:
+Alperen Akküncü The difference being, 3 and -3 are concepts created by 
humanity, rather than a fundamental particle. Because particles are made of 
matter, and Conservation of Energy exists, all that matter can't just 
disappear into nothingness. It has to go somewhere, and thus it is 
converted into energy that violently dissipates. It is like calculating the 
sun's transformation into a supernova, and the sun transforming into a 
supernova. One is a violent explosion, and the other is simply information.

comments.author: Defective Turret

comments.text:
+Defective Turret In the drawing he showed anti-neutrinos ...

But you have an excellent point: it is not conclusively known if 
anti-neutrinos are really different particles. As it stands, neutrinos are 
described in the standard model of particle physics as massless fermions, 
meaning that their anti-particles are different.

However, we know that neutrinos, although very light, do have some mass. 
One simple way to resolve this is to describe neutrinos as majorana spinors 
(meaning their anti-particles and particles are actually the same) and gain 
mass through the see-saw mechanism. Of course, there are also ways to 
describe neutrinos as massive fermions ;)

But as long as there is no conclusive evidence either way, one cannot be 
sure. There are currently a few experiments under way that might answer 
this question, but one has to keep in mind that experiments involving 
neutrinos are incredibly difficult, since neutrinos almost do not interact 
with anything. So it is possible that there will be some more inconclusive 
results. For instance: one can look for a neutrinoless double beta decay. 
If that exists, neutrinos are majorana spinors. No experimental evidence 
has shown one to exists as of now.

comments.author: Will Salmon

comments.text:
Not "takes up space" as in "has volume", but as in "stops other things from 
taking the same space." Empty space does not "take up space" in the latter 
sense. For example, I can fill a box with apples until eventually there is 
no more room to fit in more apples. However, if I keep putting "empty 
space" into a box, it will never be so full of "empty space" that I can't 
fit more in.

comments.text:
I'm not sure if this is a gross oversimplification or a flat out nonsense.
Pauli exclusion principle applies only to fermions, and not all elementary 
particles are fermions. Moreover, fermions can congregate into 
non-elementary particles, which aren't fermions.

What Pauli exclusion principle is responsible for, its the electron shells 
of atoms. But matter takes space not because of Pauli principle but because 
of fundamental forces, namely electromagnetism and strong force, which 
actually determine size of atoms and atom nuclei.﻿
comments.author: Алексей Салихов

comments.text:
Actually particle physicists use the terms "matter" and "fermion" pretty 
much interchangeably. If you attend a talk and the speakers mentions 
"matter particles", they're talking about fermions. The fact that some 
composite particles such as Helium 4 are bosons at low enough energies is 
typically ignored since that is merely a low temperature effective 
description. 

" But matter takes space not because of Pauli principle but because of 
fundamental forces, namely electromagnetism and strong force, which 
actually determine size of atoms and atom nuclei."

Not exactly. Well, it is true that the simplest atoms such as the hydrogen 
atom would look pretty much the same with a spinless electron. However, 
once you start considering multi-electronic atoms you have to consider 
interactions between electrons to get the proper shell structure (usually 
with something like Hartree-Fock as a starting point) and the fact the 
electrons are fermions makes a difference on what shells you get, not just 
how they're filled. But I guess this is mostly a technical point. What's 
important is that the stability of matter is a direct result of the Pauli 
principle:

http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/jmp/9/5/10.1063/1.1664631
http://scitation.aip.org/content/aip/journal/jmp/9/5/10.1063/1.1664631
http://www.pas.rochester.edu/~rajeev/phy246/lieb.pdf

Minutephysics was indeed sloppy when he confused "location" with "quantum 
state", however, ignoring the uncertainty principle.

comments.author: Алексей Салихов

comments.text:
Fermion: any particle characterized by Fermi–Dirac statistics. These 
particles obey the Pauli exclusion principle. Fermions include all quarks 
and leptons, as well as any composite particle made of an odd number of 
these, such as all baryons and many atoms and nuclei.

following, but if the Pauli exclusion principle basically states that you 
"can't cram too much matter into a small space", then how does that

have mass) crammed into an infinitely small amount of space.

horizon, the distance from the singularity becomes infinitesimal.
comments.author: GReaperEx

comments.text:
+Raykkie You don't accelerate faster than the speed of light. Time slows

comments.author: Buss1000

comments.text:
+Buss1000 If you consider a black hole as an object, it's an infinitely 
small object called singularity, a single point. But if you consider it as 
the whole region of space highly influenced by the singularity you now have 
what is called an Event Horizon. When you're inside the Event Horizon 
(which is really just a region of space around the sigularity) you're 
accelerating toward the  singularity faster than the speed of light. It's 
within this space that you're being infinitely compress, but when you're 
outside you would just be attracted to this like if it was a classical 
massive object. I hope you understand now, but if you have any question you 
can still reply here ^^.
comments.author: Raykkie

comments.text:
As far as I know black holes are not infinitely small. When matter gets too 
close it is just smash ridiculously thin along the surface making the black 
hole slightly bigger and does increase the gravitational pull of the black 
hole.

If black holes have infinite gravity the whole known universe would 
collapse.

I am not a mathematician or even a scientist but this is how I view it. An 
easier answer would be we really aren't sure.

comments.text:
Particles hate each other because they are the same... like two north poles

comments.author: martijn van weele

comments.text:
Particles have a certain charge which behave alike to magnetism, two 
similarly charged particles repel. eg. Electrons have elementary charge e 
which would be -1.602176565(35)×10^−19 [Coulombs] (1 Coulomb = 1 Ampere * 1 
second v 1 Coulomb = 1 Farad * 1 Volt) (To the power of -19 means 19 
decimal zero's before you get to the first number). A positron has the same 
exact charge but then positive. Particles and Anti-Particles cancel each 
other out for the same reason 1-1=0.
TL;DR: Your assumption's correct.
